fields.title: STL DSA October Movie Social
fields.description:
Join STL DSA for an October Movie Social!

We'll be screening Boots Riley's "Sorry to Bother You" on Saturday, October 1. We'll be at the Arkadin Cinema and Bar (in the backlot of The Heavy Anchor at 5228 Gravois). Doors open at 7:30 pm, and screening starts at 8 pm.

While STL DSA will provide popcorn and candy during the event, food can also be brought in from the outside. Other concessions are available for purchase. Drinks (alcoholic and non) must be purchased on-site and cannot be brought in.

Seating is provided but somewhat limited. We encourage you to bring lawn chairs or blankets, in case there aren't enough seats to go around.

We'll see you there!

fields.description:

We'll have more info on this meeting soon, but this is the annual event where STL DSA elects our Leadership Committee and Executive Committee members, passes Priority Resolutions for the upcoming year, goes over Committee and Working Group Reports and more.

Once you RSVP for this meeting, you'll receive the Zoom info you need to attend.

We'll see you there!

This is a Newbie Friendly event! If you're new to DSA and want to jump right in, this is definitely the meeting for you. We'll be discussing some of the drier details, but I like to think that this is the sort of stuff you came for. :P

This is a Newbie Friendly event! If you're new to DSA and want to jump right in, this is definitely the meeting for you. We'll be discussing some of the drier details, but I like to think that this is the sort of stuff you came for. :P

fields.title: Community Committee and Build Our Base - January 2021
fields.description:
Happy New Year everyone!

We're getting together to continue to Build STL DSA's Base by planning our inter-member canvas.  This is the fun part because we all get to meet new people and make new comrade friends! I don't know about you, but the isolation of the pandemic makes me feel out of touch with my fellow human, so I'm excited to talk to people again.

Also, we're going to revisit the Community Committee charter and do some rewrites.  Per a discussion with other leaders, we think it would be good to increase the democratic aspects of our organization by making the chair(s) of a committee elected ad hoc by membership.  Since Community Committee chair elections are coming up in March, we need to get our charter in-line for such a vote.

Let's get organizing!

Agenda

fields.title: Taking Care of St. Louis: Protecting Housing & Healthcare as Human Rights
fields.description:
Rent is skyrocketing, wages are stagnating, poverty is pervasive, and homelessness is rising. In Missouri, 540, 000 people have no health insurance and 31% of those people are Black or people of color, although they make up only up 18% of the population.

There is no question that both Housing and Healthcare are human rights. Join STL DSA for a discussion about how privatization and racial capitalism have failed to support and protect our housing and healthcare rights.

fields.title: test_event
fields.description:
The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually for now.

In the first week of STL DSA's Summer 2021 Socialist Night School, we look at a selection of readings that explore just what exactly capitalism is, how it works, and the seemingly counterintuitive way it actually helps us as socialists strategize for a future beyond it.

Recommended Readings:

"Wage Labour and Capital", Karl Marx, Chapters Eight and Nine
"Capitalism: A Ghost Story", Arundhati Roy

The idea that hard work is rewarded with a comfortable life, or that a rising tide lifts all boats are comforting just-so stories that underpin our lives—not just in the US, but across the capitalist world. The unfortunate truth, as we can see, is that in reality the vast majority of wealth and profits accumulate to a select few, who rely on exploiting the labor of the vast majority of other people, many of whom struggle just to meet their basic needs. The system that perpetuates this is, of course, capitalism, but contrary to popular mythmaking, it is not a system that is eternal or inevitable—it was created and it can be destroyed.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School Week 5: Socialist Futures
fields.description:
The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually for now.

Building a socialist future requires not only education grounded in socialism, but a set of plans that can be put into action by individuals and organizations like DSA. This week, we will be joined by representatives of the Internationalist Commune in Rojava, a group of internationalists who have participated in the social revolution going on in Northeast Syria. As we discuss building a socialist future in the United States, we are very excited to be joined by folks actively participating in the construction of alternatives to capitalism under a revolutionary, bottom-up democratic model.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School Week 4: Theories of Social Change
fields.description:
The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually for now.

In the third week of STL DSA's Summer 2021 Socialist Night School, we look at different theories of social change.

At its base, the idea of struggling against something necessitates a method by which struggle happens. The struggle against capitalism and for socialism has looked a lot of different ways historically. Sometimes, it’s a mass of workers rising up against bosses, sometimes it’s indigeneous activists working with trade unionists––no matter what the struggle looks like we have to consider how we negotiate theories of revolution and change into action for a given situation. This session surveys the big ideas surrounding the mode of struggle in socialist struggles.

Recommended Readings:

Social Movements and Progressive Governments - Marta Harnecker, and On Revolution - Marx.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School Week 3: What is Ideology?
fields.description:
The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually for now.

In the third week of STL DSA's Summer 2021 Socialist Night School, we look at the concept of ideology.

People in the US have a hard time thinking of themselves as a part of a socio-economic class. Sometimes, people on the left express this frustration through phrases like “they’re voting against their interests.” This is fine enough an explanation, but socialist philosophers, especially within the Marxist tradition, have a particularly helpful way of thinking through the phenomenon of working-class people working against their own interests. For Marx, the operative word is “ideology.”

Recommended Readings

Ralph Miliband Counter-Hegemonic Struggles, and Citations needed - Labor Shortage.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School Week 2: Race & Class
fields.description:
The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually for now.

In the second week of STL DSA's Summer 2021 Socialist Night School, we look at a selection of readings that explore the relationship between capitalism and race. The readings and discussion for this week will take both a historical view on this topic as well as root it in contemporary debates.

Recommended Readings

The first reading is an excerpt from Ralph Bunche's A World View of Race from 1936. This short 12 page chapter, “The Device of Race in World Economic and Political Conflict,” provides a nice, basic, approachable explanation of the relationship of race to economic exploitation as well as some insight on the history of race in the US.

The second reading is by Touré Reed who makes a concise contribution to the contemporary race vs. class debate. This short Jacobin article crams in a bunch of history on black political thought and organizing in addition to laying out a very clear position on this debate that we can examine and discuss in class.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School: What is Class?
fields.description:
The Fall 2020 STL DSA Socialist Night School continues!

The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually, via Zoom, at least through the end of 2020. Suggested readings are provided via hyperlinks below.

Week 4: What is Class?

Class is central to how socialists understand the world and how we think about and contest for power, but what does class mean and how does class look in the 21st century? We'll start with some basic definitions from Marx and discuss their applicability to modern economic realities and conditions.

Starting with Micheal Zweig's straightforward--if reductive-- "Six Points on Class," Monthly Review 58, no. 3 (July 2006), which provides us with a basis for a simple argument: yes, even in our de-industrialized economy the working class constitutes a majority of the population.  

In "Death of a Yuppie Dream," published by the New York office of the Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung in 2013, Barbara Ehrenreich and John Ehrenreich revisit their 1977 theorization of a 'Professional Managerial Class' (PMC) distinct from the traditional middle class as well as from the capitalist and working class. With the deskilling and professionalization of many PMC occupations has much of it become part of the working class? Was the PMC ever a distinct class at all?

Whatever we think of the class formation arguments put forward by Ehrenreich and Zweig we are left with some political questions principal among these: Does class position prefigure political orientation? Does the working class by virtue of its position in the economy hold a special place in struggles for democracy and socialism? To help us explore these questions I suggest two brief pieces with divergent conclusions, Peter Meiksins, "Beyond the Boundary Questions," New Left Review I/157, May/June 1986, and Andre Gorz, "The New Agenda," NLR I/184, November/December 1990.

It's entirely possible to have a fruitful discussion without reading all (or any!) of these pieces, but these are provided as potentially useful guideposts.

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Antiracist Socialism: Building a Multiracial Working Class Coalition
fields.description:
The Fall 2020 STL DSA Socialist Night School continues!

The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually, via Zoom, at least through the end of 2020.

This week we'll be discussing why our class struggle must also be antiracist. There are unique ways in which class and capitalism oppress people of color, so we should pay close attention to those hurdles in order to build a socialist future that functions for everyone. People of color make up a large share of the working class, so a movement that does not include them and speak to their needs cannot succeed. This requires us all to do both internal work (decolonizing our minds) and external work (building multiracial coalitions). We'll talk about the importance of antiracism in our anticapitalism and strategies for committing to it.

We'll be discussing three readings (but we encourage you to attend even if you don't read them!):
The first is an excerpt from Ibram X. Kendi's book How to be an Antiracistwhich gives a primer on how race and class are intertwined.
The second is the Combahee River Collective Statement, written by a group of Black feminists in 1977 which still functions as a guiding light for many who work on antiracism.
The third is an article by DSA comrades in Chicago about how we can go about building true cross-racial solidarity and multiracial organizations.

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School: The Fight for a Publicly Owned Future
fields.description:
The Fall 2020 STL DSA Socialist Night School continues!

The Socialist Night School is open to anybody interested in learning more about the ideas and history behind left and socialist movements. Like most STL DSA events, we will be conducting these virtually, via Zoom, at least through the end of 2020. In this week's session, we will be covering a few basic readings outlining public ownership.

A key struggle for democratic socialists is the fight for democratic public ownership of utilities to serve the people over profit for private investors. The primary goal of private ownership is profit, and when it interferes in the public sector, it seeks profit at the expense of the people. We will look at privatization as a whole and a case study of Flint, Michigan to see the danger of privatization and why we need to fight for public ownership.

This week's readings are:

"Livable Cities" by Thomas Sugrue from "We Own the Future"

and

"The Poisoning of Flint" by Diane Feeley

Hope to see you there! Note that, upon RSVPing, you will receive a message providing details for the Zoom call.

fields.title: Socialist Night School: Home School Edition (Week 8)
fields.description:
Prison Labor Class

Our next Socialist Night School focuses on Missouri Vocational Enterprises, a little-discussed state-run company that exploits low-wage prison slavery under the guise of 'rehabilitation.' We'll be talking about what MVE does, who it harms, and how we can finally defund and defeat a monument to mass incarceration, worker exploitation, and the dehumanization of incarcerated people.


Linked below is a reading that provides some background information that will be briefly presented on before jumping off into a discussion. Hope to see you there!

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fDMYeQfeUH-s1AR1ZZy4ZAq16SCgEdRX/view?usp=sharing

fields.title: Socialist Night School: Home School Edition (Week 7)
fields.description:
Our next Socialist Night School focuses on comradeship, community, and what we owe to each other—a topic of even more relevance in a time when social distancing often means "being there" is only figurative, and the dangers of alienation are more threatening to the socialist project than ever.

We will review a short reading from Jacobin (linked below), and use that as a jumping-off point for a larger discussion! Hope to see you there.

https://www.jacobinmag.com/2019/11/comrades-political-organizing-discipline-jodi-dean

fields.title: Socialist Night School: Home School Edition (Week 6)
fields.description:
St. Louis Teamsters

For our July 7th discussion we're going to delve a little bit more into St. Louis's rich radical history. There are two pieces for this session, one is a little long (but the prose is lively), the other very short, about the post-war social democratic unionism of Teamsters Local 688, and its principle leaders Harold Gibbons and Ernest Calloway. Championing an expansive, community-oriented vision of trade unionism at a time when many unions were limiting themselves to 'pure and simple unionism' the St. Louis Teamsters offer lessons into both the possibilities and limits of progressive trade unionism and of the post-war liberal state more generally.  

The longer of the two pieces, "A Trade Union Oriented War on the Slums": Harold Gibbons, Ernest Calloway and the St. Louis Teamsters in the 1960s," by Bob Bussel provides an overview of this community unionism project; Bussel later expanded into the book Fighting for Total Person Unionism: Harold Gibbons, Ernest Calloway and Working Class Citizenship, the release of which occasioned the alternate piece offered, a 2015 interview with Bussel on St. Louis on the Air.

Hope to see you on July 7th!

fields.title: Socialist Night School: Home School Edition (Week 5)
fields.description:
We are continuing our ongoing virtual night school during social distancing with a special short lecture and discussion this week on Ricardo Flores Magón, a Mexican Revolutionary in St. Louis.

"Forward, comrades! Soon you will hear the first shots; soon the shout of rebellion will thunder from the throats of the oppressed ...Land and Liberty!"

These were the words of Mexican revolutionary Ricardo Flores Magón printed in Regeneración, the bilingual anarchist newspaper published by the Magón brothers and their compañeros (commonly known as magonistas), on November 19th,1910, just one day before the Mexican Revolution began to radically transform world history. Magón, one of the political precursors to the Mexican Revolution, made this declaration not in Mexico, but in the U.S., where he had been living with other magonistas, in exile due to their radical activities. They originally fled to the Southwest U.S. and in 1904 propelled the group further away from the border, to St. Louis, Missouri.

While in St. Louis, the Magón brothers founded the Partido Liberal Mexicano (PLM, Mexican Liberal Party), which despite its name was a radical political organization rather than a party. Magón and his compañeros continued their agitation against the Mexican dictator Porfirio Díaz and projected their anarchist vision of a world without bosses or borders.

Their organizing and bonds created during their time in St. Louis would lay the foundation for long-term relationships among the radical left in both Mexico and the United States.

Readings: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1DbwNOWIzU8j3TuMQBJxE_qW_nPKCFxpS?usp=sharing

Hope to see you on the 23rd!

fields.title: Workplace Organizing Training Series Part 4
fields.description:
Hate your job? Don't quit, organize! Join St. Louis DSA's Labor Committee as we learn together from union organizers how to organize with our coworkers to build power and make our jobs suck less. Whether you want to organize your own workplace, are currently a union member but want to build a stronger fighting union, or help others organize theirs (or all three!), join us for this 4 part series and come help build a powerful working class that can change the world!

The training will be both in person and on Zoom. Please indicate which way you'll attend in the form. For in person, masks will be required at all times.

While we will not have professional childcare available, there will be a StL DSA member who is a parent watching their own kid & providing childcare to others during the training, so attendees are welcomed to bring children. The room we will be in has two rooms attached used for the church's Sunday School, so kids will always be close by. If you have any questions about childcare please reach out!

Open to all, no membership necessary!

fields.title: StL DSA Labor Fall Social

Join the StL DSA Labor Committee for a Fall social to kick off a new year of organizing! We'll have snacks and drinks and fun and solidarity for all! Whether you're interested in organizing you're own workplace but don't know where to start, you're already organizing and looking for more support outside the workplace, or just want to help support building a badass working class movement, you can find what you're looking for here!

Trinity is wheelchair accessible & has 2 gender neutral wheelchair accessible bathrooms for us to use. We will be hanging both in the garden area and inside. Masks are required while inside & optional outside. While we unfortunately won't have dedicated childcare service at this event, we strongly encourage families to bring their children. We have access to toys & kid friendly spaces in the church if needed. And we already have Labor kiddos so yours will have friends!

fields.title: Organizing Your Workplace Pt 4
fields.description:
Please register HERE.

If you’re feeling frustrated at work and thinking about quitting, you’re not alone. Workers everywhere are saying “enough” and mobilizing after decades of stagnant wages, unpredictable schedules, and lack of health care or paid sick leave.

By organizing your workplace, you can win real, lasting improvements that allow you and your co-workers to flourish in your jobs. After all, it’s your labor and cooperation that keeps the business running day after day.

STL DSA's four-part training series will take you from a new workplace organizer to a powerful force for your coworkers. We’ll guide you through everything you need to know, including how to connect with your coworkers, determining your demands, and what to expect from your boss when they push back.

fields.title: Tenant Bill of Rights Canvass
fields.description:
RSVP now to join STL DSA & Homes 4 All St. Louis for a Tenant Bill of Rights Canvass!

Together, we will hit the doors to collect pledges for a city-wide Tenant Bill of Rights & recruit tenant leaders to fight back against the abuses of slumlords.

The Demands:

  • Right to Counsel: Tenants will be automatically provided an attorney for eviction defense, paid for by the government
  • Renter Protections: Prevents discrimination in housing & guarantees the rights of renters to have safe & affordable housing; allows victims of domestic violence to break their leases without penalty and escape their abusers
  • Accessibility: Requires leases & legal notices be provided in plain language and/or native language of the renter in a timely & transparent manner in accordance with Fair Housing standards
  • Right to Organize: Provides protections for tenants to collectively organize and bargain for safe living conditions and fair treatment

When: Nov 18, 2022 at 6p

Where: The Gelateria Coffee Company, 3197 S. Grand Blvd, Saint Louis, MO 63118

Who: All who want to stand in solidarity against slumlords!

Questions? Email housing@stldsa.org!

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Week 1: Intro to Labor
fields.description:
Greetings comrades, join us for the first class of the re-launched Socialist Night School on Tuesday, February 21st! It will be the start of a series of classes on organized labor, with the first topic being an introduction to the state of labor in the US and a discussion on what it means to be an organizer. See links to the readings below:

Reading 1: The State of American Labor - An overview of current circumstances of the American workforce. Describes what challenges are faced in unionizing in the present day, and where there is potential to get workers organized.

Reading 2: Spadework - A good personal account of a labor organizer working to establish a union for their university's graduate students. Goes into the highs and lows of organizing work.

These classes are open to everyone, so feel free to spread the word to anyone interested. Because this is a live event, please be sure and bring a mask as wearing one is mandatory while indoors.

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Week 4: Future Labors
fields.description:
Hello once again comrades, join us for our fourth class of the re-launched Socialist Night School on Tuesday, April 4th! We will be continuing our classes on organized labor, with the topic this week being how workers and labor movement can recover from the grievous setbacks suffered over the past few generations. Readings and links are below:

Reading 1: Who Works for the Workers - This is an essay running down a handful of the problems facing revitalizing unions in the US, and approaches on how they can be overcome.

Reading 2: How Socialists and Trade Unionists Built a New Labor Organizing Model During the Pandemic - Workers want to be unionized, the desire is there. But what's needed is more people trained to organize workers who don't already have a union. This article goes into detail on EWOC, how it came together, how it works, and how it's delivered on providing training to new organizers.

Please note that attendance to the previous classes is not required to attend this one! These classes are open to everyone, so as always feel free to spread the word to anyone interested. Because this is a live event, please be sure and bring a mask as wearing one is mandatory while indoors.

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Week 3: Setbacks in the Labor Movement
fields.description:
Hello again comrades, join us for the third class of the re-launched Socialist Night School on Tuesday, March 21st! We will be continuing our classes on organized labor, with the topic this week being how labor lost its place of prominence in the United States in the second half of the twentieth century. The readings this time can be found on the below links:

Reading 1: U.S. Union Revitalization and the Missing "Militant Minority" - We'll be starting off with an article covering how the gradual hollowing out of the most proactive and driven union organizers (oftentimes Socialists and Communists) led to complacency and stagnation that left unions vulnerable when they came under sustained assault.

Reading 2: Hard Times for Labor, an excerpt from the book Beaten Down, Worked Up by Steven Greenhouse. These three chapters provide a broad outline of the decline of unions during and after the 80s, with numerous firsthand accounts and explanations of the tactics used to break unions.


These classes are open to everyone, so as always feel free to spread the word to anyone interested. Because this is a live event, please be sure and bring a mask as wearing one is mandatory while indoors. We've been having some excellent conversations in the past couple classes, so be sure and attend!

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Week 2: Labor & Race
fields.description:
Hello again comrades, join us for the second class of the re-launched Socialist Night School on Tuesday, March 7th! We will be continuing our classes on organized labor, with the topic this week being how race has been a factor in the American workplace. See the links below for the readings, and I hope to see you there!

Reading 1: The Politics of Labor and Race in the USA - This week's overview reading will provide an introduction into how race has shaped the development of the labor movement in the United States.

Reading 2: Justice for Janitors and Immigrant Unionism - Our second reading for this week will be an excerpt from the book "A History of America in Ten Strikes" by Erik Loomis. It focuses on the Justice for Janitors campaign and how organizing immigrant workers has helped empower unions in an era of overall decline.

These classes are open to everyone, so as always feel free to spread the word to anyone interested. Because this is a live event, please be sure and bring a mask as wearing one is mandatory while indoors.

fields.description:

Tom Oldenburg is the most reactionary remaining member of the board of Alders, and this is your chance to help get him out and get a great progressive candidate in.

New to canvassing, or concerned about doing it alone? We got you, fam! We'll pair you up with another member to give you a hand.

We'll be meeting every Saturday at 1PM, up until the primary, at CoRadius Coworking. Here's a Google Maps link: https://goo.gl/maps/qG7qHgGe52tpapBU8

Make sure to wear shoes that are comfortable for walking! Please bring a smart phone or electronic device with remote internet access (if possible). We'll be providing sunblock and water for volunteers.

See you there!

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Market Conditions of the Housing Crisis
fields.description:
Hello comrades, join us for the first of our ongoing Socialist Night School one-shot classes! Our format for the near future will be changing to having a monthly class, with each covering a new topic. This time around we'll be having a discussion about how private provision and ownership makes housing unaffordable and why the incentives of landlords and developers create rising rents alongside increasingly vacant homes. We will discuss why current reforms have failed to resolve the crisis and why we need to organize tenants and de-commodify housing to guarantee homes for all. Readings are as follows:

Reading 1 - A recent study covering the housing supply in St. Louis.

Reading 2 - This article covers the rise of rent-setting algorithms and how they've affected housing costs, as well as how landlords have been keeping houses vacant to maintain high prices.

Reading 3 - This reading gives an example of how Boston took action to curb speculation on housing by directly purchasing numerous properties.

I hope to see you there! These classes are open to everyone, so as always feel free to spread the word to anyone interested. Because this is a live event, please be sure and bring a mask as wearing one is mandatory while indoors.

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Forced Labor in U.S. Prisons: A Socialist Response
fields.description:
Hello comrades, join us for the next installment of our ongoing Socialist Night School one-shot classes! For the June class we'll examine the scope and nature of forced labor in U.S. prisons, with a particular focus on socialist critiques of the prison-industrial complex (defined in contrast to the more common market economic critique of prison labor) and the longstanding movement to secure collective bargaining rights for incarcerated workers, one potential path for socialist resistance to mass incarceration. In addition to examining these issues nationally, we'll delve into Missouri Vocational Enterprises, the manufacturing arm of the Missouri Department of Corrections, to look at how prison labor impacts both incarcerated and non-incarcerated Missourians. Readings for this class can be found with the below links:

Reading 1: The Prison Industrial Complex - An article covering the rise of "for profit prisons" and how incarceration has become a big business.

Reading 2: Union Organizing & Collective Bargaining for Incarcerated Workers - This reading covers opportunities for incarcerated workers to organize and push back against the exploitive conditions they live in.

I hope to see you there! These classes are open to everyone, so as always feel free to spread the word to anyone interested.

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Lessons from the Abolition of Slavery
fields.description:
Hello comrades, join us for the next installment of our ongoing Socialist Night School one-shot classes! As always these classes are open to everyone, so if you know anyone that might be interested, be sure and let them know.

For the July class we'll be looking back to a seminal chapter of the history of the United States. No event in US history ruptured property relations as much as the abolition of slavery. The emancipation of 4 million Black slaves represented a significant break in the social order and an opportunity to rebuild a more democratic and just nation before it was tragically abandoned and left unfinished. Antislavery public opinion and democratic mass politics in the North along with mass resistance from the Black slaves led to the revolutionary upheaval that culminated in the abolition of slavery. In this class we will look at what can we, as democratic socialists, learn from this Second American Revolution?

Reading 1 - "The General Strike" by W.E.B. Du Bois (from Black Reconstruction)

Reading 2 - "The Mass Politics of Antislavery" by Matt Karp (from The Catalyst)

UCity Comrades!

fields.title: StL Art + Labor People's Campaign Launch
fields.description:
This project proposes an approximately two-hour workshop with a selection of union
locals/labor organizations in the St. Louis area. The workshop contains two components: an introduction to the history of American labor movements as it has manifested in posters and print, with the 1877 St. Louis general strike in particular focus as a historical event. The second component introduces participants to printing and how to create their own poster designs and slogans using provided printing materials. Each participant will walk away with their very own screen-printed poster (or a few) which they are encouraged to post in visible locations in their communities as a call to organized labor.
Drawing inspiration from the voices and creativity of the workshop participants, the Lead Facilitator will create and mass produce a new poster as well. A number of these will be shared with the partnering union locals/labor orgs to distribute and display around high-traffic areas in their respective communities.

fields.title: Afrosocialists & Socialists of Color Book Discussion Pt. 4
fields.description:
STL DSA Afrosocialists & Socialists of Color Caucus (AfroSOC) is hosting a book discussion on Octavia Butler's Kindred.

More than 35 years after its release, Kindred continues to draw in new readers with its deep exploration of the violence and loss of humanity caused by slavery in the United States, and its complex and lasting impact on the present day. Adapted by celebrated academics and comic artists Damian Duffy and John Jennings, this graphic novel powerfully renders Butler’s mysterious and moving story, which spans racial and gender divides in the antebellum South through the 20th century.

We will be reading and discussing the book Thursdays in May, 7-8:30 PM. (May 6,13, 20, and 27). AfroSOC will also provide a copy of the book to members, so please let us know if you'd like one while registering. The first book discussion is reserved for BIPOC folks (Black, Indigenous, people of color).

RSVP for Zoom link.

fields.title: AfroSOC February Meeting
fields.description:
Afrosocialists & Socialists of Color Caucus is kicking off 2021! We'll reconnect, set some goals and plans for the year, and share some time for healing. Agenda will be sent out a week prior to the meeting.

This space is for BIPOC folks only (Black, Indigenous, people of color).


AFROSOC advocates for and builds power with DSA's Black/POC membership and their communities. We pursue this work to help build a multiracial working-class base, the only viable strategy for securing a socialist future. Through public and internal education and agitation, we aim to continue the legacy of the Black radical tradition, as well as the radical traditions of other oppressed minorities. Our goal is to act as a network that will support and develop non-white DSA members as leaders in the organization.

fields.title: AfroSOC December Movie Night
fields.description:
Join us for the next Afrosocialists & Socialists of Color Caucus (virtual) movie night! Please enter your address when registering as we'll drop off some snacks prior to the event! Also vote on your movie selection. Options for December are:

  • Tigertail: In this multi-generational drama, a Taiwanese factory worker leaves his homeland to seek opportunity in America, where he struggles to find connection while balancing family and newfound responsibilities.
  • Daughters of the Dust: Languid look at the Gullah culture of the sea islands off the coast of South Carolina and Georgia where African folk-ways were maintained well into the 20th Century and was one of the last bastions of these mores in America. Set in 1902.
  • Jingle Jangle: An imaginary world comes to life in a holiday tale of an eccentric toymaker, his adventurous granddaughter, and a magical invention that has the power to change their lives forever.

We'll start with some quick check ins then begin the movie. Please respect that we'd like this event to be a space for BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, People of Color) only.

fields.title: Table for Strike Ready in Tower Grove Park
fields.description: StL DSA Labor will be tabling outside Tower Grove Farmers Market to talk to people about our Strike Ready campaign supporting a potential UPS workers strike, and how people can organize at work. No experience necessary!

fields.title: UCity PILOTs Campaign - Planning Meeting [Members Only]
fields.description:
UCity Comrades!

Do you find the current extractive relationship between WashU and UCity infuriating and are intrigued by the possibility of building a campaign powerful enough to renegotiate the relationship in a way that not only materially improves the lives of the UCity working class but also increases their control over public resources?

If so, we want you to join us for our next campaign building discussion on Sunday, August 13th at 1PM. We will likely try to hold this meeting at the UCity library. We'll reach out again with more details once we're closer to the date.

Please RSVP to his form to join the discussion!

Solidarity,

Michael T. and Luke E.

fields.title: Solidarity Summer Tabling
fields.description:
Solidarity Summer is heating up! Between Starbucks Worker United, UPS Teamsters, and other local fights workers have an action packed summer. Join us at Tower Grove Farmer's Market to talk to community members about how they can get involved in fighting for worker power.

We'll be set up from 9 until 12ish or whenever folks are ready to pack up! We'll be set up in the same place as last time, on the corner of Northeast Drive and Center Cross Road by the Marvin and Eileen Blackgum Tree. If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org.

fields.description: Join the August 2023 St. Louis DSA Chapter Meeting! Agenda will be sent out before the meeting.

fields.title: STL DSA Electoral Working Group Meeting
fields.description:
This meeting, we'll be following up on our "future of EWG" discussion by fleshing out the key planks of a more formalized STL DSA political platform.

What do we want from our elected representatives? What do we expect from our endorsed candidates? What should be key priorities from a socialist perspective for your municipality, your ward, your district? Let's work together to help STL DSA build a clear, consistent political message.

Agenda: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Al49OzMgUBxKVWFMbifKtu4rpkMpeOGAd7f2s0VI9kM/

fields.title: Labor Committee Strategy Session
fields.description: We are hosting our third quarterly session for the Labor Committee! This is the time where members of the committee come together to make decisions about our priorities for the next several months. This strategy session we'll be focusing on drafting the Labor Committee resolution for the September General Meeting. This meeting is intended for members who have been active in the Labor Committee in the past several months but is open to all. We'll be in North Parish Hall in Trinity Church and masks will be required. The space is child friendly and if you would like childcare please reach out to labor@stldsa.org ASAP. If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org

fields.title: Pol Ed Presents - Museum Tours - St Louis Freedom Struggle, 1821-1968
fields.description:
Hello comrades, the Political Education Committee is pleased to announce the long-overdue return of our museum trip initiative! This will be a FREE event for chapter members who wish to participate, and this time we'll be heading to the Missouri History Museum in Forest Park. This event will consist of two parts, with the first hour being devoted to a guided, interactive tour covering the architecture of St. Louis. The second hour will consist of a private presentation for the group covering the role that St. Louis has had during its history in the battle for fair and equitable treatment for all.

Please RSVP if you are POSITIVE that you can attend on the date and time. Once you RSVP, you will be contacted via email to confirm that you are able to attend (please check your spam folder for communications). There are a limited number of tickets for this tour, so PLEASE wait for secondary follow-up to confirm that a ticket is available for you.

fields.title: Monthly Drop-in
fields.description:
Join STL DSA for our Monthly Drop-in at Earthbound Beer. We'll be there from 6 to 8 pm to share info about STL DSA and our current work, as well as hang out with fellow comrades.

It's a great way to learn more about the chapter and figure out how you want to get involved.

We'll see you there!

fields.title: StL Art + Labor People's Campaign Launch
fields.description:
The Art + Labor People's Campaign is a year-long union local-driven poster campaign to promote labor solidarity around St. Louis.

For this launch event, the approximately two-hour workshop will contain two components: a brief survey of the history of American labor movements as it has manifested in posters and print, and second component which introduces participants to screen printing and how to create their own poster designs and slogans using provided printing materials. Each participant will walk away with their very own screen-printed poster (or a few) which they are encouraged to post in visible locations in their communities as a call to support organized labor.

Spots are limited. All supplies are provided. Don't wear anything that you're afraid to get a little dirty!

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Capital and Climate Change
fields.description:
Hello comrades, join us for the next installment of our ongoing Socialist Night School one-shot classes! As always these classes are open to everyone, so if you know anyone that might be interested, be sure and let them know.

Our August class will explore how capital and the Anthropocene extinction are fundamentally inseparable. The class will include two reading discussions on capital's relationship to ecological catastrophes and a socialist framework for a path to sustainable energy. We will also provide up-to-date science on the current extent of climate change and habitat destruction. Readings can be found in the links below, I hope to see you there!

Reading 1 - "Socialist Politics and the Electricity Grid" by Matt T. Huber & Fred Stafford (from the Catalyst)

Reading 2 - An excerpt from "The Enemy of Nature" by Joel Kovel

fields.description:
Join us for the monthly Community Committee Work Day on Saturday, September 9th from 10am - 1pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, 600 N. Euclid Ave 63108.

We will be in North Parish Hall. You can park in the front lot of the church (to the left of the big red double front doors, looking at the church from Euclid). Enter through the single red door under the red awning and enter the first room on the left. The room is also accessible by going up the wheelchair ramp on the left side of the building (facing it from the parking lot) and entering the door.

We will have coffee, snacks, and lunch at noon.

In Solidarity,

Lauren P. and Michael T., Co-Chairs

STL DSA Community Committee

fields.description:

This will be a potluck, so please bring food to share. If you need childcare for the event, please contact us (at info@stldsa.org) in advance us so we can set it up!

If you are unable to attend in person, we are offering a hybrid option where you can still vote and participate. But it is important for you to RSVP because we need to be able to set people up for voting ahead of time. Please RSVP to get the Zoom link to the meeting.

We'll see you there!

fields.title: UAW Local 2250 Strike Ready Rally
fields.description:
Join STL DSA comrades in supporting UAW Local 2250 members as they gear up to potentially go on strike! UAW is currently negotiating their contract with the Big 3 Automakers, GM, Ford, and Stellantis which expires on September 14th. Members in Wentzville recently voted over 97% to authorize a strike and do whatever it takes to get the contract they deserve!

On September 10th, members and community supporters will be rallying outside the Local 2250 union hall and we want to make sure they know that STL DSA has their back! We'll be organizing carpools so let us know if you are interested in driving, need a ride, or if you'll be going yourself. We look forward to seeing you there!

fields.title: North St. Louis County Caucus Regular Meeting
fields.description: This is a regular meeting of the North St. Louis County Caucus. We will meet in a virtual and a hybrid meeting on a biweekly basis. This is a virtual meeting for the Caucus.

fields.title: Transit Caucus Meeting
fields.description:
Sustainable transit is essential to uphold the values of climate justice and accessibility. Building a truly diverse and multiracial working-class movement should include organizing for reliable transit options.

Join the Transit Caucus on Zoom to discuss the role of the caucus within our chapter!

fields.title: SBWU Solidarity Day of Action
fields.description:
After almost two years and over 300 stores unionizing, Starbucks workers still don't have a contract. The bosses have done everything possible to delay bargaining while they continue to intimidate and harass workers. That's why on September 14th, customers and supporters are coming together to show Starbucks that we are not backing down.

Join STL DSA and SBWU St. Louis at two stores in the area for an informational picket to talk to community members about the no contract, no coffee pledge. First we'll be at 4656 Maryland Ave from 7 - 8 AM and then we'll head to 6622 Chippewa St from 8 - 9 AM.

fields.title: KIPP Informational Picket RSVP
fields.description:
Staff at KIPP St. Louis High School won their last year, becoming a first in our city and in the country! They want a contract and almost a year later still do not have one. On September 14th, teachers and allies are coming together to show KIPP that they mean business by hosting an informational picket outside the school.

Join STL DSA in supporting KIPP teachers as they fight for better working conditions and better schools!The picket will be running from before the school day to after school and they are looking for supporters to join them throughout the day.

fields.title: UAW Local 2250 Strike Ready Rally
fields.description:
Join STL DSA comrades in supporting UAW Local 2250 members as they gear up to potentially go on strike! UAW is currently negotiating their contract with the Big 3 Automakers, GM, Ford, and Stellantis which expires on September 14th. Members in Wentzville recently voted over 97% to authorize a strike and do whatever it takes to get the contract they deserve!

On September 10th, members and community supporters will be rallying outside the Local 2250 union hall and we want to make sure they know that STL DSA has their back! The rally starts at 12 PM with speakers going on at 1 PM. We'll be organizing carpools so let us know if you are interested in driving, need a ride, or if you'll be going yourself. We look forward to seeing you there!

fields.title: Socialist Night School - A Brief History of the German Socialists in St. Louis
fields.description:
Hello comrades, we have reached the penultimate Socialist Night School class for this year! As always these classes are open to everyone, so if you know anyone that might be interested, be sure and let them know. This month's class will be presented by journalist Devin O'Shea and will be covering the story of German Socialists in St. Louis!

Through lifting weights, drinking beer, and committing armed revolutionary emancipation, German immigrants had a profound effect upon politics and culture in St. Louis. Much of that history has been erased over the course of two world wars and the Red Scare. This lecture will provide an ideological overview of what socialism and communism meant in 1848, what distinguished Germans from other classes of immigrants arriving in America, the lasting socialist influence won in the aftermath of the American Civil War, and why the German influence on St. Louis and the Midwest is largely forgotten.

Readings can be found below:

"Socialist Gym Rats Fought to End Slavery," in Jacobin

"From Slavery Abolition to Public Education, German Radicals Made American History," in Jacobin

Devin O'Shea's writing is in Slate, The Nation, Jacobin, Protean, Current Affairs and elsewhere. @devintoshea on twitter, @devintoshea on Instagram.

Join STL DSA for our Monthly Drop-in at Earthbound Beer on Wednesday, October 11th, from 6 to 8 pm.

fields.title: UAW Day of Action
fields.description:
Members of UAW Local 2250 were the first called on in this historic Big 3 Stand Up Strike and have been holding the line since September 15! While DSA members have been out standing in solidarity on the picket line almost everyday so far we're excited to be doing a big visit day from the chapter. So join us on September 30th from 4 - 8 PM in Wentzville to walk the picket line, talk with UAW members, and show our support.

We will be organizing carpools and transportation so let us know if you can give a ride or would like a ride. Depending on where you are carpools will be leaving between 3 - 3:30 so we can be there at 4 PM. Wear red and your walking shoes! If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org

fields.title: UAW Day of Action Part 2
fields.description:
UAW is calling on community supporters to participate in a day of action on Saturday, October 7th! So join STL DSA and chapters across the country on October 7th from 12 - 4 PM in Wentzville to walk the picket line, talk with UAW members, and show our support.

We will be organizing carpools and transportation so let us know if you can give a ride or would like a ride. Depending on where you are carpools will be leaving between 11 - 11:30 so we can be there at 12 PM. Wear red and your walking shoes! If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org

fields.title: Labor Committee October Meeting
fields.description:
Join us for our monthly labor committee meeting! If you're interested in the work we're doing in labor this is a great place to start. We talk about things like our ongoing projects and campaigns, political education, and general discussions about the work of the committee and the chapter. So if you're a longtime member, new to the chapter, or DSA curious we hope to see you there!

These meetings are hybrid so you can join us in Trinity or via Zoom. If you'll be joining in person you can arrive starting at 6:30 PM. You'll have some time to meet other comrades and share a potluck dinner. Then the meeting will begin at 7:00 for both in-person and Zoom folks. We'll also be providing childcare if needed so let us know in the form! Masks are required and if you're feeling sick please join us via Zoom.

fields.title: Workplace Organizing Training Series Part 4
fields.description:
Hate your job? Don't quit, organize! Join St. Louis DSA's Labor Committee as we learn together from union organizers how to organize with our coworkers to build power and make our jobs suck less. Whether you want to organize your own workplace, are currently a union member but want to build a stronger fighting union, or help others organize theirs (or all three!), join us for this 4 part series and come help build a powerful working class that can change the world!

The training will be both in person and on Zoom. Please indicate which way you'll attend in the form. For in person, masks will be required at all times. Childcare is available for participants.

There are 4 sessions total, each week on the same night, and participants are highly encouraged to attend all four trainings as they build on each other.

Open to all, no membership necessary!

So if you're a longtime member, new to the chapter, or DSA curious we hope to see you there!

These meetings are hybrid so you can join us in Trinity or via Zoom. If you'll be joining in person you can arrive starting at 6:30 PM. You'll have some time to meet other comrades and share a potluck dinner. Then the meeting will begin at 7:00 for both in-person and Zoom folks. We'll also be providing childcare if needed so let us know in the form! Masks are required and if you're feeling sick please join us via Zoom.

fields.title: Community Committee Kickoff Strategy Potluck
fields.description:
The Community Committee is back!

Our resolution and budget passed at the September General Meeting, and now it’s time to start planning another year of socials, trainings, projects, and more! If you like throwing parties, planning events, helping comrades find their footing in the chapter, manipulating spreadsheets, or asking people for money, then we’ve got important work for you to do and we need your help!

Join us for a Kickoff Strategy Potluck on Saturday, October 21st from 10am - 1pm at Trinity Church.

See you there!

Solidarity,

STL DSA Community Commitee

fields.title: Kickoff Power Mapping Meeting - Green New Deal Working Group
fields.description:
Calling all ecosocialists!

Even as University City and St. Louis are afflicted by climate change-driven catastrophes of increasing frequency and severity, powerful institutions not only avoid taking responsibility but actively suck resources out of our communities.

One of the worst examples of this trend is WashU, who's ever-expanding, sprawling web of tax-exempt properties robs University City and St. Louis of the public resources necessary to build climate-ready communities.

If you find the current extractive relationship between WashU and cities of UCity and St. Louis infuriating and are intrigued by the possibility of building a movement powerful enough to renegotiate that relationship in a way that materially improves the lives of the working class and increases their control over public resources, then join the Green New Deal Working Group on Sunday, October 22nd at 1pm in the auditorium of the University City Public Library for our first meeting planning our newest campaign: A Green New Deal for St. Louis, Starting With Our Schools.

Together, we will build and wage a campaign demanding that WashU enter a payment-in-lieu-of-taxes (PILOTs) agreement with our cities to fund the transformation of our public schools into green, community-centered hubs, ready for an uncertain climate future.

Please bring a computer if you have one because we'll be power mapping together (don't worry if you don't know what that is). Please wear a mask.

Solidarity,

The Green New Deal Working Group

fields.title: Pol Ed Presents - Walking Tours - The Hidden History of Forest Park
fields.description:
Hello comrades, the Political Education Committee is proud to present the next installment of our field trip initiative! We're changing things up a bit and this time we'll actually be taking a guided walking trip of Forest Park. The park is a well-known centerpiece of St. Louis, but for this tour we'll actually be covering the less well-known histories of its landmarks. And by "less well-known," I mean the things the history books prefer to leave out on account of making people look bad.

As with past trips, please RSVP if you are POSITIVE that you can attend on the date and time. Once you RSVP, you will be contacted via email to confirm that you are able to attend (please check your spam folder for follow-up communications).

fields.title: Socialist Night School - Conspiracy Theories in the United States
fields.description:
Hello comrades, I am happy to report that we are bringing to a close this year's run of Socialist Night Schools! We have covered a number of diverse topics and I am proud of how so many in our chapter have lent their time and knowledge for the benefit of everyone. Don't worry though, SNS will return with new courses and material in early 2024! And there is still one class left!

Join us for the final SNS class of 2023, as we take a look at conspiracy theories in the United States. Widespread paranoia and mistrust has been a hallmark of our nation for its entire history, and you can look forward to a brief overview of how these theories have shaped the culture and behavior of it. After the overview we'll be going over individual theories as a group. Just a disclaimer, this is going to be a little more light-hearted class, and participants are strongly encouraged to share their favorite theories. The more outlandish the better, because everybody loves fringe weirdness. No readings required, and you can expect food and drinks to be served.

fields.title: STL DSA October Chapter Meeting
fields.description:
It's our October chapter meeting! We'll be electing formation chairs and voting on a number of resolutions from the September general meeting that were moved to this month due to time constraints.

Meeting agenda to follow soon!

fields.title: October Leadership Committee Meeting
fields.description: The Leadership Committee meetings serve as a space for Formation co-chairs to discuss various strategy, tactics, and policy, and are open to any members of DSA to attend and observe.

fields.title: UAW Day of Action Part 3
fields.description:
As of October 15th, Local 2250 members will officially have been on strike for one month and they need our support! So join STL DSA to show solidarity with these members in Wentzville to walk the picket line, talk with UAW members, and grill up some hot dogs and hamburgers.

We will be organizing carpools and transportation so let us know if you can give a ride or would like a ride. Depending on where you are carpools will be leaving between 1 - 1:30 so we can be there at 2 PM. Wear red and your walking shoes! If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org.

fields.title: Labor Comm TG Farmer's Market Tabling
fields.description:
Striketober is in full swing! UAW workers at Local 2250 have been on strike for a month, fighting for a historic contract. STL DSA has been supporting workers on the picket line and we'll be talking to community members about the importance of this strike for all working people. We're also kicking off our next Workplace Organizing Training series where workers can come learn how to unionize their job. There's lots to talk about so come join us for a lovely fall farmer's market day!

We'll be set up from 9 until 12ish or whenever folks are ready to pack up! We'll be set up in the same place as last time, on the corner of Northeast Drive and Center Cross Road by the Marvin and Eileen Blackgum Tree. If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org.

fields.title: No Money for Massacres! STL DSA Phonebank for Palestinian Solidarity
fields.description:
Please join us this Monday, October 16, from 6-8pm CT—we will be making calls to end the siege on Gaza, end US funding for war crimes and ethnic cleansing, and tell Congress no money for massacres!

To attend, you must be a DSA member in good standing. Please RSVP with the email associated with your membership!

fields.title: Transit Caucus Meeting
fields.description:
Sustainable transit is essential to uphold the values of climate justice and accessibility. Building a truly diverse and multiracial working-class movement should include organizing for reliable transit options.

Join the Transit Caucus on Zoom to discuss the role of the caucus within our chapter!

fields.description:

We will be organizing carpools and transportation so let us know if you can give a ride or would like a ride. Depending on where you are carpools will be leaving between 10 - 10:30 so we can be there at 11 AM. Wear red and your walking shoes! If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org.

fields.title: Communications Committee Meeting - November 2023
fields.description:
Join the Communications Committee for our monthly meeting on Thursday, November 16, at 6:30 pm (via Zoom).

Once you RSVP, you'll get the link you need to join the Zoom call.

We'll see you there!

fields.title: Community Committee Work Day & Potluck
fields.description:
Join us for the monthly Community Committee Work Day & Potluck on Saturday, November 11th from 10am - 1pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, 600 N. Euclid Ave 63108.

We will be in North Parish Hall. You can park in the front lot of the church (to the left of the big red double front doors, looking at the church from Euclid). Enter through the single red door under the red awning and enter the first room on the left. The room is also accessible by going up the wheelchair ramp on the left side of the building (facing it from the parking lot) and entering the door.

Please RSVP to get access to the potluck food sign-up form.

See you there!

Solidarity,

STL DSA Community Committee

fields.description:
As of November 5, UAW members at Local 2250 will have been on strike for 50 days, and are staying strong against GM's greed. So join STL DSA to show solidarity with these members in Wentzville to walk the picket line, talk with UAW members, and grill up some hot dogs and hamburgers.

We will be organizing carpools and transportation so let us know if you can give a ride or would like a ride. Depending on where you are carpools will be leaving between 11 - 11:30 so we can be there at 12 PM. Wear red and your walking shoes! If you have any questions email labor@stldsa.org.

fields.title: STL DSA December Social
fields.description:
Join STL DSA for a December Social! We'll be meeting at Earthbound Beer on December 13 from 6-8pm to hear from speakers, enjoy drinks and food, and hang out with comrades.

All are welcome (including non-members - please, come!)!

Childcare will be provided. Masking is welcome when indoors.

fields.title: STL DSA New Member Orientation
fields.description:
We will be in North Parish Hall. You can park in the front lot of the church (to the left of the big red double front doors, looking at the church from Euclid). Enter by going up the wheelchair ramp on the left side of the building (facing it from the parking lot) and entering the door.

We will have food and drinks. Masks are mandatory while inside.

fields.description:

Come grab a beverage, hang out with comrades and talk about building a better world. It's a great way to learn more about STL DSA, meet other members and find ways to get involved.
